content.description: Read the following poem carefully before you choose your answers.Effie Waller Smith’s poem “The Recompense” was published in 1909.The Recompense1reward O ancient ocean, with what courage stern Thy tides, since time began, have sought to gain The luring moon, toward which they rise in vain, Yet daily to their futile aim return.5Like thee do glorious human spirits yearn And strive and fail and strive and fail again Some starlike aspiration to attain, Some light that ever shall above them burn. Yet truly shall their recompense abide10To all who strive, although unreached their goal: The ceaseless surgings of the ocean tide Do cleanse the mighty waters which they roll, And the high dreams in which it vainly sighed Make pure the deeps of the aspiring soul.
content.question: Which of the following best describes the speaker’s perspective on “all who strive” (line 10) ?

choices.label: The speaker finds it unfortunate that their goals may never be reached and pities them for trying.
The speaker thinks their efforts are valuable even if those efforts do not appear to be entirely successful.
The speaker dismisses them as overly idealistic and predicts that they will eventually be deeply disappointed.
The speaker is exasperated by their striving and feels that their energies would be better directed elsewhere.

content.answer: The speaker thinks their efforts are valuable even if those efforts do not appear to be entirely successful.

skill.text: Skill 4.C: Identify and describe details, diction, or syntax in a text that reveal a narrator's or speaker's perspective.
